thread.title_full: Eating for two in pregnancy but mums and babies at risk, UNSW study finds | The Advertiser

author: Sue Dunlevy National Health Reporter
title: Eating for two in pregnancy but mums and babies at risk, UNSW study finds | The
text:
EXCLUSIVE
MUMS don’t need to eat for two during pregnancy, says a ground breaking New Australian study that calls for dietary guidelines to be reviewed.
The University of NSW suggests metabolic changes in pregnant women allow them to conserve more energy and extract more calories from food so they can lay down the fat stores needed for a healthy pregnancy without eating more.
Changes in gut bacteria in pregnant women and resistance to insulin and leptin — a hormone associated with the feeling of being full — also allow them to extract more energy from food.
And it warns women who do eat a lot more during pregnancy may put on too much weight, putting them at risk of pregnancy complications including gestational diabetes and pre-eclampsia.
The mother could become obese and her baby could be at risk of premature death from heart disease, it says.
In harm’s way ... Both mother and baby are at risk if mum gains too much weight while pregnant. Picture: Thinkstock. Source: ThinkStock
Other research has found the diet of both mother and baby in the first three years of life can set food and taste preferences and determine the risk of obesity.
More than 50 per cent of pregnant women gain more weight than that the recommended 11-16 kilograms, particularly those who are already overweight or obese, says UNSW researcher Professor O’Sullivan .
And he says advice that pregnant women need to raise energy intake needs to be reassessed.
“These findings suggest the need for reassessment of nutritional advice given to pregnant women, as current advice to increase energy intake may be increasing the risk of excessive gestational weight gain,” he said.
The study published in the Australian and New Zealand Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology followed 26 women throughout their pregnancy and monitored their diet and weight gain.
Sixteen normal weight, five overweight and five obese women took part and were studied at three time points: 12-14 weeks, 24-26 weeks and 34-36 weeks of gestation.
Keeping track ... Women in the study had to record a three day food diary several times. Picture: Thinkstock. Source: ThinkStock
The women provided a diary of what they ate over a three-day period in the first, second and third trimester of their pregnancy.
Sydney’s St George Hospital used mobile sensor technology to track the women’s weight gain, energy spent and food intake.
It found their calorie intake remained steady throughout the pregnancy at around 2066, or 8649 kilojoules.
On average, the women gained 10.8 kilograms during pregnancy, seven kilograms of which was additional fat mass, largely put on between the first and second trimester.
This laying down of fat stores occurred despite an almost 8 per cent surge in daily energy demand and no significant change in food intake, the study says.
Interestingly, the study found body fat percentage change was significantly higher for women of normal BMI compared with women who were overweight or obese.
Keeping a buffer ... Normal weight women put down more fat stores than overweight women during pregnancy. Picture Thinkstock. Source: ThinkStock
Fat stores are essential in pregnancy to buffer fluctuations in energy supply and demand driven by the growing foetus, as well as the significant energy demands of breastfeeding, particularly in the first six weeks following birth, says Professor O’Sullivan.
Other research has found mice fed gut bacteria from women in their third-trimester of pregnancy put on more fat than mice fed first-trimester gut bacteria, despite both groups eating the exact same diet and exercising the same amount.
“Stool studies from women in the late stages of pregnancy also show evidence of reduced energy loss,” Professor O’Sullivan said.
“Pregnancy-related changes in gut microbiota could potentially allow pregnant women to absorb more calories from their diet for fat storage without changing the caloric or macronutrient intake, he said.
 The diet mums-to-be need to stop
